title: Thrifty mum creates incredible £150 playroom under the stairs for her daughter
text:

A thrifty mum created a magical playroom under the stairs for her daughter for just £150.

Sophie Griffiths made the budget hideaway with her DIY enthusiast dad, with the pair buying wood, wallpaper, paint and artificial flowers for the project.

Her two-year-old girl Daisy loves the new den - to the delight of her parents who wanted to keep her bedroom toy-free.

Ms Griffiths, from Newport, Wales, said the project has helped make her and her husband's new house feel like a 'home'.

(Image: Sophie Griffiths/LatestDeals.co.uk)

(Image: Sophie Griffiths/LatestDeals.co.uk)

She told money saving website LatestDeals.co.uk: "My husband and I recently bought our first home and upon purchasing it, I immediately started looking for ideas to decorate and turn our house into a home.

“Creating an inviting, child-friendly play area was top of my list, however I also wanted to have a tidy, toy-free room at night once she went to bed.

"As the stairs is situated in our living and dining room, I saw the perfect opportunity to use the space underneath.

(Image: Sophie Griffiths/LatestDeals.co.uk)

(Image: Sophie Griffiths/LatestDeals.co.uk)

"My daughter absolutely loves playing in her new playhouse and it has made a great feature in our new home!"

She scoured Google and Pinterest to source inspiration for the den, before settling on the 'playhouse' design.

Her dad bought timber and plywood from the local handyman store, faux wood wallpaper and fake flowers from Wilko, and paint from B&Q.

(Image: Sophie Griffiths/LatestDeals.co.uk)

They also reused an old storage crate to hold the flowers in the window, The Sun reports.

Anyone interested in making their own playhouse will need a saw, drill, sander, hammer, paintbrush and screwdrivers, Ms Griffiths said.

The following materials are also needed: timber for the frame, plywood for the front and door, skirting board, wood effect wallpaper, filler, screws, nails and hinges.
description: Sophie Griffiths, from Newport, Wales, wanted to build a child-friendly area where her daughter could play to keep her bedroom toy-free
